awd_titl_txt: Manufacturing USA: Precision Alignment of Roll-to-Roll Printing of Flexible Paper Electronics Through Modeling and Virtual Sensor-based Control
awd_abstract_narration:
Demand is increasing for advanced manufacturing technologies that can print electronics accurately and at high speed. Roll-to-Roll printing techniques that can continuously transfer a printed electronic pattern onto a flexible substrate are very promising for high-volume production of flexible electronic devices. However, there is a significant challenge to overcome, which is that multilayer printed electronics have very tight alignment tolerance requirements, and there are no reliable tools available to monitor and control the overlay registration accuracy in real-time. To overcome this challenge, this award develops precision alignment of roll-to-roll printing using modeling and virtual sensor-based control. Another challenge is the overwhelming use of plastic as the substrate, which are manufactured from petroleum-based materials and therefore are not biodegradable, making them environmentally hazardous to produce and dispose. To address these challenges, this award pursues paper substrates as recyclable and environmentally friendly alternatives to plastic for flexible electronics. This interdisciplinary project transcends the boundaries of several important fields, including advanced materials engineering, cyber-manufacturing and data analytics. The knowledge attained from this project helps catalyze new technologies in nano and micro additive printing that feed into the innovation pipelines of the Manufacturing USA Institutes. The outcomes of this research benefit next-generation ecologically-friendly flexible electronics, such as, greener disposable sensors for patient care or lower-cost embedded home electronics. Educational activities promote interdisciplinary capstone projects and increase students? hands-on learning experience in manufacturing research. This supports the nationwide effort in educating the next generation manufacturing engineers.

The goal of this project is to advance the fundamental understanding of roll-to-roll (R2R) printing of functional paper electronics. The study involves understanding the mechanism for spatial variation generation and its propagation and accumulation. The knowledge on spatial error propagation is used to develop virtual sensing to achieve unprecedented control in the creation, integration and manipulation of multilayer microstructures that form the foundation of printed paper electronics. Furthermore, this project studies materials-process-control-device performance relationships in a closed loop approach. This research expedites intelligent R2R systems with high traceability, predictability and controllability for high-resolution additive printing of flexible paper electronics, enabling a host of technologies spanning sensing, biomedical devices, and renewable energy. The development of R2R printing of electronics on paper ushers in a new era of environmentally-friendly, flexible paper devices such as water quality sensors at throwaway prices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Roll-to-Roll (R2R) printing techniques have emerged as a promising approach for high-volume continuous production of substrate-based products. This method contrasts with the sheet-to-sheet (S2S) approach, which is more suited for low-volume work. However, the transition from conventional S2S to high-speed R2R production has been hindered by challenges in meeting the tight alignment tolerances required for additive multi-layer printed electronics, typically at the micrometer scale. During the project period, significant achievements have been made  to overcome these challenges. Project Outcomes are summarized as follows:

  1. Data-Driven Model Predictive Control (DD-MPC) Method: This novel approach was developed to minimize multistage register errors effectively. It handles multi-input and multi-output systems and uses sensor data to obtain the plant model through the Eigensystem Realization Algorithm (ERA) and Observer Kalman filter identification (OKID) system identification method. The method is effective even for systems with partially measurable system states.
  2. Spatial-Terminal Iterative Learning Control (STILC) with PID Control: A groundbreaking method that iteratively brings registration error to zero. The STILC-PID hybrid approach has proven its convergence and effectiveness in simulating and correcting registration errors caused by axis mismatch in R2R systems. The method's capability to eliminate registration error after a reasonable number of iterations was demonstrated, including analysis on the influence of different learning gains.
  3. Advanced Imaging for real-time registration error detection: The sub-award team provided vital registration information through high-resolution imaging systems and image processing algorithms. These tools were crucial for identifying and calculating registration errors, serving as inputs for the aforementioned control methods.
  4. Innovative R2R Flexographic Printing for Electrodes: A unique method was developed for R2R flexographic printing of electrodes for lithium-ion batteries. This approach utilized eco-friendly materials like recyclable and biodegradable paper, demonstrating exceptional printability.

Intellectual Merits include (1) Understanding of Spatial Variation: The project provided a fundamental understanding of the mechanism of spatial variation generation, its propagation, and accumulation. (2) Virtual Sensing Development: The research led to the development of virtual sensing techniques, enabling unprecedented control in the creation, integration, and manipulation of multilayer microstructures. (3) Materials-Process-Control-Device Performance Relationship: New knowledge was gained regarding the relationships among materials, processes, control mechanisms, and device performance, adopting a closed-loop approach.

Broader Impacts: (1) Advancement of Intelligent R2R Systems: The project significantly advanced intelligent R2R systems with enhanced traceability, predictability, and controllability, particularly for high-resolution additive printing of flexible paper electronics. (2) Environmental Benefits and New Applications: The development of R2R printing of electronics on paper heralds a new era of environmentally-friendly, flexible paper devices. It opens doors to various applications, including affordable water quality sensors. (3) Educational and Collaborative Aspects: Student Engagement: The project involved over six graduate students and three undergraduate students, with a focus on inclusivity, as evidenced by the recruitment of students from underrepresented minority groups. Collaborative Efforts: The collaboration between Northeastern University and UMass Amherst played a crucial role in the success of the project. Dissemination of Knowledge: Results of the project have been widely disseminated through multiple conferences, seminars, and presentations, contributing to the broader scientific community, including the ASME International Conference of Additive Manufacturing, the ASME Conference of Manufacturing Science and Engineering (MSEC), seminars at Northwestern University, Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WP), UMass Amherst, and various presentations at Northeastern University.

In summary, the project successfully addressed the challenges in R2R flexible electronics printing, bridging the gap between traditional S2S and modern R2R techniques. Through innovative control schemes and collaborative efforts, the project not only advanced the field of printed electronics but also paved the way for environmentally sustainable practices and diverse applications, leaving a lasting impact on both the scientific community and the environment.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/25/2023
Modified by: Xiaoning Jin
